posts.name: Sophia D.
posts.cooked: We are trying to use the REV Blinkin for our robot this year but we’re having trouble trying to configure the different lights to shine whenever we press a certain buttons. We planned on having purple (0.91) shine whenever one button is pressed, yellow (0.69) when a different color is pressed, then hot pink( 0.57) when nothing else is active. Could anyone help us with trying to translate this into actual code?

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked: Can you share what you’ve already tried and describe in what way it wasn’t working for you?

posts.name: Sophia D.
Jeremy Martinez
posts.cooked: The Rev Blinkin should be plugged into a PWM output of the RoboRio and you would program it just like you are programming a motor.  Here is a link to a teams github that has very basic code.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Mentor of FRC 2405 & 6094 FTC 11531,18092 & 8932 Alum of 1254

posts.custom_user_title: Mentor of FRC 2405 & 6094 FTC 11531,18092 & 8932 Alum of 1254

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked:
Youre right, that definitely won’t work, but let’s talk through why.

You have a Spark object representing the PWM connection to the blinkin, right?

So what does Spark.set(…) do?

Youre defining variables for each color, but what type are they? What does Spark.set(…) have as a return type?

You then use those color variables to call .set(boolean).  I can tell youre hoping to turn each color on/off independently, but why do you think that doesn’t work?

A PWM output is a single output, meaning it doesn’t make sense to be able to assign multiple values (think what would happen if you set both yellow and purple to true).

Instead, you should definitely have those color variables, but they should be constants, and they should be numeric types (likely a double ).  Then later on, you should set the value of your Spark object to the appropriate color value (using the constant).

posts.name: Sophia D.
Fletch
posts.cooked:
Please be sure to format code properly using triple backticks (```) before and after the block of code.  Otherwise it’s very difficult to read.  That said, a link to github (or similar) is always preferred.

As for your code, that all looks reasonable (assuming you intend to hold down the button).  I’d check the wiring.  Ensure your 3-wire PWM cable is connected to the roborio port labeled “PWM 0”, and that the white wire is farthest from the edge of the roborio (pin should be labeled “S” on the far end of the row of PWM ports).  Then trace that same wire to the other end (ensuring there’s no flip-flop if there’s any intermediate connections) and confirm the white/red/black wires connect to the ~/+/- pins respectively (note the first is a tilde not a hyphen)

posts.name: Sophia D.
posts.cooked: This is my first time making a forum on chiefdelphi, thank you for telling me about how to format the code correctly. I won’t be able to adjust the wires until Saturday. I let you know how it works out. Thank you for helping me out!

posts.name: Jeremy Martinez
posts.cooked:
I have also noticed from a wiring standpoint, with the Blinkin specifically, that the PWM cable going into the Blinkin seems like its fully inserted into the connection but more often than not it is not making connection.  I have to check that connection after my students wire it up because that is almost always the failure point for us.  We have been using the Blinkin for years now in both FRC and FTC and it is a very good LED controller and easily programmed as long as it is setup correctly.  After checking your wiring you should be off and running with it!  Also very fun to have the programmers put in little “Easter egg” modes once you get confident with your programming.

We always have our LEDs change states to an end game state to notify the driver.  There are many visual feed back options that you are opening up when having the Blinkin on your robots.  Have fun with it!
